content.raw:
Another possibility would be not adding this message now, since no one will use it, and only add it once we have a use for it. The RGBD sensor would only publish color and depth images for now, but no Ignition point cloud.

CC @scpeters @iche033
content.html:
Another possibility would be not adding this message now, since no one will use it, and only add it once we have a use for it. The RGBD sensor would only publish color and depth images for now, but no Ignition point cloud.

CC @scpeters @iche033

content.raw: I would prefer to wait to merge this message until we have a plan for using it in case we need to change it
content.html: I would prefer to wait to merge this message until we have a plan for using it in case we need to change it

update.description:

PR that utilizes this message: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/70/
update.title: Adding pointcloud color

content.raw:
## Update

For performance and ease of implementation, we're not going to bridge this message to ROS for now, and instead we'll write a plugin that directly publishes the ROS message. The sensor on `ign-sensors` will publish this message for now, but there will be no consumers (i.e. no way to visualize this message using Ignition or ROS).
content.html:
Update

For performance and ease of implementation, we're not going to bridge this message to ROS for now, and instead we'll write a plugin that directly publishes the ROS message. The sensor on ign-sensors will publish this message for now, but there will be no consumers (i.e. no way to visualize this message using Ignition or ROS).

content.raw: `Added a pointcloud_color message ...`
content.html: Added a pointcloud_color message ...

content.raw: Let me know when you think it's safe to merge this PR.
content.html: Let me know when you think it's safe to merge this PR.

content.raw: good question. it's a bit more verbose in a potentially useful way to do `msg.projection().P(i)` compared to `msg.P(i)`, though I guess it must add some overhead as well
content.html: good question. it's a bit more verbose in a potentially useful way to do msg.projection().P(i) compared to msg.P(i), though I guess it must add some overhead as well

content.raw: I'm ok with that. And this brings the question of whether we need a Projection message at all.
content.html: I'm ok with that. And this brings the question of whether we need a Projection message at all.

content.raw: I think I was trying to follow our (implicit ?) style of using lowercase on messages, but I don't feel strongly about it.
content.html: I think I was trying to follow our (implicit ?) style of using lowercase on messages, but I don't feel strongly about it.

content.html: call this K to match the ROS message?

content.raw: +1 to matching the ROS message

content.raw: good point; I was comparing the comments, but you are write that they pass the entire matrix. I support matching the ROS message
content.html: good point; I was comparing the comments, but you are write that they pass the entire matrix. I support matching the ROS message

content.raw: The same applies to the `Projection` matrix below.

content.raw: Thanks, I'll change and document the parameters expected for each of the 3 models.
content.html: Thanks, I'll change and document the parameters expected for each of the 3 models.

content.raw: The ROS message uses `float64[9]  K`, so even though it's not documented, users can define skew if they need to.
content.html: The ROS message uses float64[9] K, so even though it's not documented, users can define skew if they need to.

content.raw:
yeah, the ROS message uses an array too, so I think this makes sense.

for reference, I think the equidistant model uses 4 parameters:

* https://github.com/ethz-asl/kalibr/blob/14e47ea0edb7a42efa03533855e533f9e6ad7bb8/aslam_cv/aslam_cameras/src/EquidistantDistortion.cpp
* linked from https://github.com/ros/common_msgs/pull/109
content.html:
yeah, the ROS message uses an array too, so I think this makes sense.

for reference, I think the equidistant model uses 4 parameters:

  • https://github.com/ethz-asl/kalibr/blob/14e47ea0edb7a42efa03533855e533f9e6ad7bb8/aslam_cv/aslam_cameras/src/EquidistantDistortion.cpp
  • linked from https://github.com/ros/common_msgs/pull/109

content.raw:
the current message matches [sensor_msgs::CameraInfo](http://docs.ros.org/melodic/api/sensor_msgs/html/msg/CameraInfo.html), which also doesn't have axis skew

so it seems like a trade-off between parity with the ROS message and adding more flexibility
content.html:
the current message matches sensor_msgs::CameraInfo, which also doesn't have axis skew

so it seems like a trade-off between parity with the ROS message and adding more flexibility
